title: Section 1

\(\sigma\)-algebras
In the STAT 210 textbook, we defined a \(\sigma\)-algebra as follows:
Definition 2.2.1 from textbook

Definition 1 A \(\sigma\)-algebra on \(\Omega\) is a collection \(\mathcal{F}\) of subsets of \(\Omega\) such that:

\(\emptyset \in \mathcal{F}\).
If \(A \in \mathcal{F}\), then \(A^c \in \mathcal{F}\).
If \(A_1, A_2, \cdots \in \mathcal{F}\), then \(\cup_{j=1}^{\infty} A_j \in \mathcal{F}\).

Show that \(\sigma\)-algebra is automatically closed under countable intersections, i.e.¬†if \(A_1, A_2, \cdots\) are in the \(\sigma\)-algebra \(\mathcal{F}\), then \(\cap_{j=1}^{\infty} A_j \in \mathcal{F}\). Then, show that the requirement \(\emptyset \in \mathcal{F}\) can be replaced by the requirements \(\mathcal{F} \neq \emptyset\).

Tip: De Morgan Laws



\[\left(\bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n \right)^c = \bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n ^c.\]
\[\left(\bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n \right)^c = \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} A_n ^c.\]




‚úèÔ∏è Pencil 2.2.6
Check that an intersection of \(\sigma-\)algebras, even uncountably many, is \(\sigma\)-algebra. Give a simple example showing that a union of \(\sigma\)-algebras may not be a \(\sigma\)-algebra.






Solution





Will be added after section. üòõ 









As noted in the textbook as well as Hazard 2.2.2, a \(\sigma\)-algebra \(\mathcal{F}\) is a collection of sets, and an element of \(\mathcal{F}\) is a subset of \(\omega\). An intersection of \(\sigma\)-algebras is very different from an intersection of events!

Borel \(\sigma\)-algebras
Definition 2.3.1 from textbook

Definition 2 The Borel \(\sigma\)-algebra \(\mathcal{B}\) on \(\mathbb{R}\) is defined to be the \(\sigma\)-algebra generated by all open intervals \((a,b)\) with \(a,b\in \mathbb{R}\). A Borel set is a set in the Borel \(\sigma\)-algebra.

Show that the Borel \(\sigma\)-algebra is the same if we use closed intervals \([a,b]\) instead of open intervals to generate it, and that it is also the same if we use ‚Äúsemi-inifinite‚Äù intervals \((-\infty,b)\) to generate it.

Probability Measure
Section 2.5 from textbook

Definition 3 A probability space \((\Omega, \mathcal{F}, P)\) consists of a measurable space \((\Omega, \mathcal{F})\) and a map (the probability function) \(P\) satisfying the following axioms:

\(P(\emptyset) = 0\), \(P(\Omega) = 1\).
\(\forall A \in \mathcal{F}\), \(P(A) \geq 0\).
If \(\{A_i\}^{\infty}_{i=1}\) is a collection of mutually disjoint sets in \(\mathcal{F}\), i.e.¬†\(\forall i \neq j\), \(A_i \cap A_j = \emptyset\), then \[P\left( \bigcup_{i=1}^{\infty} A_i \right) = \sum_{i=1}^{\infty} P(A_i). \] \end{itemize} This property is known as \(\sigma\)-additivity.



‚úèÔ∏è Pencil 2.5.1
Show that in the first axiom, the condition \(P(\emptyset) = 0\) can be eliminated.

title: Section 1
text:
Random Variables and Random Vectors
Definition 2.6.1 from textbook

Definition 4 A random variable is a measurable function \(X\) from \(\sigma\) to \(\mathbb{R}\), where ‚Äúmeasurable‚Äù means that the preimage \(X^{-1}(\mathcal{B}) = \{\omega \in \sigma : X(\omega) \in \mathcal{B}\}\) is in \(\mathcal{F}\) for all Borel sets \(\mathcal{B}\).


Definition 5 A random vector in \(\mathbb{R}^n\) is a measurable function \(\mathbf{X}\) from \(\sigma\) into \(\mathbb{R}^n\), where ‚Äúmeasurable‚Äù means that the preimage \(\mathbf{X}^{-1} (\mathcal{B}) \equiv \{\omega \in \sigma: \mathbf{X}(\omega) \in \mathcal{B}\}\) is in \(\mathcal{F}\) for all Borel sets \(\mathcal{B}\) in \(\mathbb{R}^n\).

title: Section 1
text:
Limits of Events
Section 2.8 from textbook

Definition 6 Let \(A_1, A_2,...\) be a sequence of events on \((\Omega, \mathcal{F}, P)\). Define
\[B_n = \bigcup_{m=n}^{\infty} A_m ,\hspace{0.2cm} C_n = \bigcap_{m=n}^{\infty} A_m, \hspace{0.2cm} n\geq 1 .\]
Then, \(C_n \subseteq A_n \subseteq B_n\), $n $, and \(\{B_n\}^{\infty}_{n=1}\) and \(\{C_n\}^{\infty}_{n=1}\) are decreasing and increasing respectively. Let \(B\) and \(C\) be their respective limiting sets. Then,
\[B = \bigcap_{n=1}^{\infty}\bigcup_{m=n}^{\infty} A_m ,\hspace{0.2cm} C = \bigcup_{n=1}^{\infty} \bigcap_{m=n}^{\infty} A_m  \] We call \(B\) and \(C\), \(\limsup\limits_{n \to \infty}A_n\) and \(\liminf \limits_{n \to \infty}A_n\), respectively.

Show that \(B = \{\omega \in \Omega : \omega \in A_n \text{ for infinitely many values of } n\}\).

Preface
This website contains section notes for STAT 210: Probability I, a graduate level probability course at Harvard University taught by Professor Joe Blitzstein. These notes are created by Zad Chin and Jarell Cheong Tze Wen.

text:
Logistics
